segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā parittaṃ nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsuṃ āropetvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
segments.en: Then the Buddha, picking up a little bit of dirt under his fingernail, addressed the mendicants:

segments.pli: katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ—yo vāyaṃ mayā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito, ayaṃ vā mahāpathavī”ti?
segments.en: Which is more: the little bit of dirt under my fingernail, or this great earth?”

segments.pli: “Etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yadidaṃ—mahāpathavī; appamattakāyaṃ bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito.
segments.en: “Sir, the great earth is certainly more. The little bit of dirt under your fingernail is tiny.

segments.pli: Saṅkhampi na upeti, upanidhampi na upeti, kalabhāgampi na upeti mahāpathaviṃ upanidhāya bhagavatā paritto nakhasikhāyaṃ paṃsu āropito”ti.
segments.en: Compared to the great earth, it can’t be reckoned or compared, it’s not even a fraction.”

segments.pli: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, appamattakā te sattā ye manussesu paccājāyanti; atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā ye aññatra manussehi paccājāyanti.
segments.en: “In the same way, the sentient beings reborn as humans are few, while those not reborn as humans are many.
It’s because they haven’t seen the four noble truths.

segments.pli: Dukkhassa ariyasaccassa … pe … dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ariyasaccassa.
segments.en: The noble truths of suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

segments.pli: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yogo karaṇīyo … pe … ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yogo karaṇīyo”ti.
segments.en: That’s why you should practice meditation …”
